text-xs u-margin-xs-bottom access-type-label-only"><div class="AccessLabel"><span class="access-indicator"></span>Full text access</div></div><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><section class="ReferencedArticles"></section><div class="PageDivider"></div><div class="Abstracts u-font-serif" id="abstracts"><div class="abstract author-highlights" id="abs0001"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Highlights</h2><div id="abss0001"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara009"><ul class="list"><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0001">Coal-derived hard carbon material used as <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/sodium-ion-batteries" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a> anode.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0002"><span>Preparation <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a> anode through NaOH activated and </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-coating" title="Learn more about surface coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface coating</a>.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0003">Closed pores enable efficient storage of <a href="/topics/food-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> in the <a href="/topics/engineering/plateau-region" title="Learn more about plateau region from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">plateau region</a>.</span></div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0004"><a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-layer" title="Learn more about Carbon layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Carbon layer</a> coating reduces disorder and improves rate and cycling performance.</div></span></li><li class="react-xocs-list-item"><span class="list-label">•</span><span class="list-content"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0005">The specific capacity of CNA1200 is 335.2 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup> with ICE=51.53 %.</div></span></li></ul></div></div></div><div class="abstract author" id="abs0002"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Abstract</h2><div id="abss0002"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara010"><span>Pore structure engineering has been acknowledged as suitable approach to creating active sites and enhancing ion transport capabilities of hard carbon anodes. However, conventional porous carbon materials exhibit high BET and surface defects. Additionally, the <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage mechanism predominantly occurs in the slope region. This contradicts practical application requirements because the capacity of the plateau region is crucial for determining the actual capacity of batteries. In our work, we prepared a novel “core-shell” carbon framework (CNA1200). Introducing closed pores and carboxyl groups into coal-based carbon materials to enhance its sodium storage performance. The closed pore structure dominates in the “core” structure, which is attributed to the timely removal of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) to prevent further formation of active carbon structure. The presence of closed pores is beneficial for increasing sodium ion storage in the low-voltage plateau region. And the “shell” structure originates from coal tar pitch, it not only uniformly connects hard carbon particles together to improve cycling stability, but is also rich in carboxyl groups to enhance the reversible sodium storage performance in slope region. CNA1200 has excellent electrochemical performance, it exhibits a specific capacity of 335.2 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> at a current density of 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup> with ICE = 51.53 %. In addition, CNA1200 has outstanding cycling stability with a capacity retention of 91.8 % even when cycling over 200 times. When CNA1200 is used as anode paired with Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode, it demonstrates a capacity of 109.54 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1 C and capacity retention of 94.64 % at 0.5 C. This work provides valuable methods for regulating the structure of sodium-ion battery (SIBs) anode and enhances the potential for commercialization.</div></div></div><div class="abstract graphical" id="abs0003"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Graphcal abstract</h2><div id="abss0003"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara011"><span class="display"><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0009"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-ga1.jpg" height="200" alt="Image, graphical abstract"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-ga1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (266KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (266KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-ga1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span></figure></span></div></div></div></div><ul id="issue-navigation" class="issue-navigation u-margin-s-bottom u-bg-grey1"><li class="previous move-left u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-left"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-left" href="/science/article/pii/S1005030224005887"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-left"><path d="M1 61l45-45 7 7-38 38 38 38-7 7z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Previous <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span></a></li><li class="next move-right u-padding-s-ver u-padding-s-right"><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-tertiary u-display-flex button-alternative-icon-right" href="/science/article/pii/S1005030224005450"><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">Next <span class="extra-detail-1">article</span><span class="extra-detail-2"> in issue</span></span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg></a></li></ul><div class="Keywords u-font-serif"><div id="keys0001" class="keywords-section"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Keywords</h2><div id="key0001" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0002">Hard carbon, plateau region</span></div><div id="key0002" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0003">NaOH controlled etching-thermal annealing</span></div><div id="key0003" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0004">Closed pore structure</span></div><div id="key0004" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0005">Carboxyl groups</span></div><div id="key0005" class="keyword"><span id="cetext0006">Coal-based carbon materials</span></div></div></div><div class="Body u-font-serif" id="body"><div><section id="sec0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0005" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">1. Introduction</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0006">Lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) face challenges in meeting the growing energy demand due to their low abundance and uneven distribution [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0001" name="bbib0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">1</span></span></a><span>]. Among various alternative secondary <a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a> technologies, sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) stand out because of their abundant resources and low cost [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0002" name="bbib0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[2]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0003" name="bbib0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[3]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0004" name="bbib0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[4]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0005" name="bbib0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[5]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0006" name="bbib0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[6]</span></span></a>]. However, the larger radius of Na<sup>+</sup><span> leads to slower ion transport kinetics, resulting in poor <a href="/topics/food-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a><span> storage performance of graphite which is widely used as <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode material</a> for LIBs [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0007" name="bbib0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">7</span></span></a>]. Therefore, the key to achieving commercialization of SIBs lies in finding suitable anode materials. Carbon materials have emerged as one of the most promising anodes for SIBs due to their wide variety and low cost [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0008" name="bbib0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[8]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0009" name="bbib0009" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0009"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[9]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0010" name="bbib0010" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[10]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0011" name="bbib0011" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0011"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[11]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0012" name="bbib0012" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0012"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[12]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0013" name="bbib0013" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0013"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[13]</span></span></a>]. Among them, hard carbon stands out with obvious advantages. It has the capability to surpass the thermodynamic bound, reaching a capacity of 300 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> and operating at a low voltage of 0.3 V [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0015" name="bbib0015" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">15</span></span></a>]. To accelerate the development of SIBs, selecting appropriate hard carbon precursors and modification methods is crucial for the development of hard carbon.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0007"><span>Recently, coal products have attracted great interest such as <a href="/topics/engineering/lignite" title="Learn more about lignite from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">lignite</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a><span>], <a href="/topics/engineering/bituminous-coal" title="Learn more about bituminous coal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">bituminous coal</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0017" name="bbib0017" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0017"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">17</span></span></a><span>], <a href="/topics/engineering/anthracite" title="Learn more about anthracite from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anthracite</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>], and coal tar pitch [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0019" name="bbib0019" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0019"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">19</span></span></a>]. In 2016, Li et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a><span>] conducted a pioneering study that demonstrated the feasibility of using high <a href="/topics/engineering/coalification" title="Learn more about coalification from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coalification</a> anthracite-based carbon materials in SIBs, it has a reversible capacity of 222 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup><span>. However, the low interlayer spacing resulting in its specific capacity was far from ideal for commercialization. Constructing <a href="/topics/engineering/porous-structure" title="Learn more about porous structures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">porous structures</a> can effectively enhance ion transfer kinetics and increase active sites [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0020" name="bbib0020" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0021" name="bbib0021" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0021"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21</span></span></a><span><span>]. However, highly open porous structure has more <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/surface-defect" title="Learn more about surface defects from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface defects</a><span> and higher BET, which mainly manifests as the adsorption of <a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage in the slope region. This is not conducive to improving the actual capacity of battery, because the actual specific capacity of hard carbon is mainly determined by the </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/plateau-region" title="Learn more about plateau region from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">plateau region</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0014" name="bbib0014" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0014"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">14</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0022" name="bbib0022" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0022"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22</span></span></a>]. Therefore, introducing closed pores instead of open pores has become an efficient strategy to balance the capacity and electrochemical stability of coal-derived carbon.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0008"><span><span>Long-flame coal (CY) is a subclass of <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/bituminous-coal" title="Learn more about bituminous coal from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">bituminous coal</a> that is commonly used as power fuel due to its low degree of </span><a href="/topics/engineering/coal-metamorphism" title="Learn more about coal metamorphism from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coal metamorphism</a> and price (400 $ ton</span><sup>−1</sup>), which will cause significant pollution and waste. Previous research reports have confirmed the potential of low-rank coals for energy storage. In 2020, Abou-Rjeily et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0023" name="bbib0023" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0023"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">23</span></span></a><span><span>] obtained a low-rank coal-derived carbon material by simple high-temperature <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization</a>, but it exhibited poor </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> and only had a storage capacity of 254 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup>. In 2020, Zou et al. [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0016" name="bbib0016" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0016"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">16</span></span></a>] obtained a lignite-derive carbon material with a storage capacity of 256 mAh g<sup>−1</sup><span><span>. Therefore, rationally regulating the microstructure of CY-derived carbon materials also can enable it to be applied in the <a href="/topics/engineering/energy-storage-application" title="Learn more about energy storage applications from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">energy storage applications</a>. Compared with other coal-based derived carbon materials, CY stands out due to its unique porous structure, which exhibits diverse </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-structure" title="Learn more about pore structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore structure</a> composition at different temperatures [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0024" name="bbib0024" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0024"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">24</span></span></a>]. This provides prerequisites for engineering the microstructure of CY-derived carbon.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0009"><span><span><span>In our work, a novel coal-based <a href="/topics/engineering/derived-carbon-material" title="Learn more about derived carbon material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">derived carbon material</a><span> (CNA1200) was prepared. Closed pores and <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/carboxyl-group" title="Learn more about carboxyl groups from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carboxyl groups</a> (-COOR) were co-introduced into CNA1200 by NaOH-controlled etching-thermal annealing and </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/surface-coating" title="Learn more about surface coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface coating</a>. CNA1200 has a rich “core” of closed </span><a href="/topics/engineering/nanopore" title="Learn more about nanopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanopores</a><span><span> and a dense carbon “shell” of -COOR. Compared with previous studies, we chose NaOH as pore-forming agent and removed it before thermal annealing. This strategy not only improved the electrochemical activity of CY, but also avoided it becoming an active <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-structure" title="Learn more about carbon structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon structure</a>, ultimately improving its sodium storage performance in plateau region. At the same time, the abundance of -COOR on the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/layer-coating" title="Learn more about coating layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating layer</a><span> can increase the number of active sites in slope region and further improve rate performance and cycling stability. Under the <a href="/topics/engineering/synergistic-effect" title="Learn more about synergistic effect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">synergistic effect</a><span> of NaOH-controlled etching-thermal annealing and <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-coating" title="Learn more about surface coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface coating</a>, the specific capacity of CNA1200 is increased to 335.2 mAh g</span></span></span></span><sup>−1</sup>. It also has excellent rate performance and cycling stability (with a capacity retention of 91.8 %). This novel modification strategy increases plateau region performance without sacrificing slope region capacity, demonstrating a new way to develop advanced hard carbon materials for SIBs.</div></section><section id="sec0002"><h2 id="cesectitle0006" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2. Experimental section</h2><section id="sec0003"><h3 id="cesectitle0007" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.1. Pre-cleaning of coal samples</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0010"><span>CY was supplied by Huangyuchuan coal mine (Ordos, Inner Mongolia, China) with fixed carbon of 43.97% and ash content of 17.2% (Table S1). It contains more impurities, which has a detrimental impact on the material's <a href="/topics/food-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> storage capacity. In order to remove these impurities, it is usually treated with 6 mol L</span><sup>−1</sup><span><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/hydrochloric-acid" title="Learn more about hydrochloric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrochloric acid</a> (HCl) and 40 wt% </span><a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/hydrofluoric-acid" title="Learn more about hydrofluoric acid from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">hydrofluoric acid</a> (HF) (Fig. S1 in the Supplementary Material).</span></div></section><section id="sec0004"><h3 id="cesectitle0008" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.2. Synthesis of ACM</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0011">For synthesis of amphiphilic carbon material (ACM), 20 g of coal tar pitch was placed in a mixed solution of H<sub>2</sub>SO<sub>4</sub> and HNO<sub>3</sub> (<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-6-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>H</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>S</mi><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; transform="translate(583,-155)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-48"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(530,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(851,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-53"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1245,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(550,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-34"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">H</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-6"><math><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">H</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msub></mrow></msub></math></script></span>:<span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-7-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mtext is=&quot;true&quot;>HN</mtext><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>O</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>3</mn></msub></mrow></msub></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="6.077ex" height="2.548ex" viewBox="0 -747.2 2616.3 1096.9" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.812ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-56"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(583,-155)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-48"></use><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4E" x="750" y="0"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1061,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-4F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(550,-107)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-33"></use></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">HN</mtext><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub></mrow></msub></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-7"><math><msub is="true"><mi is="true">V</mi><mrow is="true"><mtext is="true">HN</mtext><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">O</mi><mn is="true">3</mn></msub></mrow></msub></math></script></span><span> = 7:3) and oxidized at 80 °C for 1 h. Then, the obtained raw product was put into NaOH solution and reacted at 25 °C for 3 h. The <a href="/topics/engineering/coating-material" title="Learn more about coating material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coating material</a> ACM was obtained by thoroughly washing until pH = 7.</span></div></section><section id="sec0005"><h3 id="cesectitle0009" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.3. Preparation of “core-shell” carbon materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0012"><span>CY and NaOH (CY: NaOH = 1:4) were homogeneously mixed in the water and reacted for 6 h at 60 °C. When the reaction is completed, wash it to remove NaOH. After drying, the sample was placed in tubular furnace and <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbonization" title="Learn more about carbonization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonization</a><span> in an argon atmosphere for 2 h, where the carbonization temperature was 1200 °C and the <a href="/topics/engineering/heating-rate" title="Learn more about heating rate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">heating rate</a> was 2 °C min</span></span><sup>−1</sup><span>. And it was named CN1200. Furthermore, CN1200 and ACM were evenly mixed in water with a ratio of 1:10 and heated at 80 °C for 3 h. Then the solid precursors were placed into tube furnace for carbonization reaction. It was carbonized in an <a href="/topics/engineering/ar-atmosphere" title="Learn more about Ar atmosphere from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ar atmosphere</a> with a temperature of 1200 °C for 2 h. The “core-shell” carbon material (CNA1200) was obtained. For comparison, CY was also carbonized in a tube furnace at 1200 °C to obtain CY1200.</span></div></section><section id="sec0006"><h3 id="cesectitle0010" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.4. Material characterization</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0013"><span><span><span><span>The <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a> and carbon </span><a href="/topics/engineering/microcrystalline" title="Learn more about microcrystalline from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microcrystalline</a> structure were analyzed through Scanning </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about Electron Microscope from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Electron Microscope</a> (SEM) (FEI Verios 460) and High-Resolution Transmission Electron Microscope (HRTEM) (FEI Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN). And the crystal characteristic information of the material was studied using X-ray diffraction (XRD) spectrum (Bruker D8 Advance), in which the wavelength of Cu/K X-ray </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffractometers" title="Learn more about diffractometer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffractometer</a><span> was 1.5405 Å. Further, the Raman spectrometer (Thermo Scientific DXRxi) was used to examine crystal structure and <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/surface-defect" title="Learn more about surface defect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface defect</a><span><span>. Further X-ray <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about photoelectron spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">photoelectron spectroscopy</a> (XPS) spectra (AXIS SUPRA) were obtained to analyze the surface chemical composition and elements contained in material. The </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-structure" title="Learn more about pore structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore structure</a> information was further investigated using N</span></span></span><sub>2</sub> adsorption/desorption tests (Quantachrome Autosorb IQ3), small-angle X-ray scattering tests (SAXSess mc2) and true density test (AccuPyc II 1340).</div></section><section id="sec0007"><h3 id="cesectitle0011" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">2.5. Electrochemical measurements</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0014"><span>The active substance, conductive carbon (Ketjen black EC600JD), and <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/vinylidene" title="Learn more about Polyvinylidene from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Polyvinylidene</a> Fluoride (PVDF) were blended together with a mass ratio of 8:1:1 in N-Methylpyrrolidone (NMP) solvent and coated on Al foil. It is worth noting that the weight of the active substance on the Al foil remained at 1–2 mg. And electrolyte consisted of 1 M (mol L</span><sup>−1</sup>) of NaClO<sub>4</sub><span><span><span><span> dissolved in <a href="/topics/engineering/ethylene-carbonate" title="Learn more about Ethylene carbonate from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Ethylene carbonate</a> (EC) and Dimethyl Carbonate (DMC) with a volume of 1:1. Sodium foil served as counter electrodes and </span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/fibreglass" title="Learn more about glass fibers from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">glass fibers</a> (GF/F, Whatman) served as separator. The initial Coulombic efficiency of the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a><span><span> was further improved by pre-electrical treatment. Before assembling the battery, the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode material</a> coupled with </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium" title="Learn more about sodium from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium</a> foil is immersed in the electrolyte to illuminate the </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/lightbulb" title="Learn more about light bulb from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">light bulb</a>. The cathode Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> (NVP) was prepared using a similar method. Assemble the full cell using CNA1200 and NVP. The mass ratio of the two electrodes was controlled at ≈ 1:2 (anode: cathode). A series of electrochemical measurements were performed on carbon material. The charge/discharge test was conducted using a CT3001A device (Wuhan LAND). <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about Cyclic Voltammetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Cyclic Voltammetry</a> (CV) and electrochemical impedance spectra (EIS) tests were tested on an electrochemical workstation (PARSTAT3000A-DX, Princeton Applied Research). The CV scan rates were set at 0.1 to 1 mV s</span><sup>−1</sup> with a voltage range spanning from 0.01 to 2.5 V. For EIS tests, a frequency range of 100 kHz–0.01 Hz was employed with an amplitude voltage of 5.0 mV.</div></section></section><section id="sec0008"><h2 id="cesectitle0012" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3. Results and discussion</h2><section id="sec0009"><h3 id="cesectitle0013" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.1. Preparation and characterization of CY-derived carbon anode materials</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0015"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0001" name="bfig0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 1</span></span></a><span><span> illustrates the synthetic process of CY-derived carbon <a href="/topics/materials-science/anode-material" title="Learn more about anode materials from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">anode materials</a><span>. During the co-heating process of coal and NaOH, the activated carbon atoms will react with NaOH and carbon skeleton will be etched to form an open pore structure (Table S2). In order to avoid the formation of traditional active carbon materials, NaOH should be removed promptly after the reaction is completed. And open pores generated by NaOH activation will be converted into closed pores during the slow heating process, thus achieving a new carbon skeleton (CN1200) with closed pores as main pore structure. In order to improve rate performance and not sacrifice the capacity of the slope region, we conducted <a href="/topics/engineering/coating-material" title="Learn more about ACM coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">ACM coating</a>. ACM was an amphiphilic </span></span><a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/carbonaceous-material" title="Learn more about carbonaceous material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbonaceous material</a><span> and had many -COOH functional groups. And the hydrophobic region of ACM was nonpolar, leading to intermolecular attraction with CN1200. Therefore, it can be evenly coated on the surface of CN1200 and obtain CNA1200 rich in -COOH functional groups and <a href="/topics/engineering/closed-pore-structure" title="Learn more about closed pore structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">closed pore structure</a>.</span></span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0001"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr1.jpg" height="208" alt="Fig 1" aria-describedby="cap0001"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr1_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (224KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (224KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr1.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0001"><p id="spara001"><span class="label">Fig. 1</span>. Schematic diagram for the fabrication of CY-derived <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about carbon anode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon anode</a> materials.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0016"><span><span>The <a href="/topics/engineering/surface-morphology" title="Learn more about surface morphology from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface morphology</a> of hard carbon was observed by </span><a href="/topics/engineering/scanning-electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a>. As shown in </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(a, b), CY1200 exhibited lumpy particles with a size of 500–650 nm (Fig. S2(a–c)). Its surface was rough with some cracks. CN1200 will shrink due to the collapse of pores and cracks during the <a href="/topics/engineering/annealing-process" title="Learn more about annealing process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">annealing process</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(c, d)). After <a href="/topics/materials-science/surface-coating" title="Learn more about surface coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface coating</a><span>, a dense <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-layer" title="Learn more about carbon layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon layer</a> evenly covered the surface of CN1200 (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(e)). It can greatly reduce the contact area between electrodes/electrolytes, thereby forming thinner <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/solid-electrolyte" title="Learn more about solid electrolyte from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">solid electrolyte</a> interface (SEI) film (Fig. S3(a, b)). The elemental mapping supported the successful coating of ACM, and the N elements that originated from ACM were uniformly distributed on the CNA1200.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0002"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr2.jpg" height="650" alt="Fig 2" aria-describedby="cap0002"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr2_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (2MB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (2MB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr2.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0002"><p id="spara002"><span class="label">Fig. 2</span>. <span>(a–d) SEM images of CY1200 and CN1200; (e) SEM images and <a href="/topics/materials-science/energy-dispersive-x-ray-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about EDX from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">EDX</a> mapping of C, N, and O elements of CNA1200; (f–h) HRTEM, </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/selected-area-diffraction" title="Learn more about SAED from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAED</a><span> and <a href="/topics/engineering/fast-fourier-transform" title="Learn more about FFT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">FFT</a> images of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0017"><span><span><span>To characterize the state of carbon <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/microcrystals" title="Learn more about microcrystals from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microcrystals</a>, </span><a href="/topics/engineering/high-resolution-transmission-electron-microscope" title="Learn more about HRTEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">HRTEM</a> and corresponding selected area </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-diffraction" title="Learn more about electron diffraction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electron diffraction</a> (SAED) were conducted (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0002" name="bfig0002" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 2</span></span></a><span>(f–h)). CY1200 showed <a href="/topics/engineering/disordered-structure" title="Learn more about disordered structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">disordered structure</a><span> with defects and turbine-like <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanocrystalline-material" title="Learn more about nanostructures from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanostructures</a><span>. After NaOH-controlled etching-thermal annealing, CN1200 exhibited more <a href="/topics/engineering/nanopore" title="Learn more about nanopore from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanopore</a> structures. According to the sodium storage mechanism, nanopores were beneficial for providing more active sites [</span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0025" name="bbib0025" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0025"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">25</span></span></a>]. However, due to the limitations of TEM testing, it was not possible to determine whether these nanopores were closed or open. CNA1200 had more orderly parallel lattice stripes compared to CY1200 and CN1200. The reduction of surface disorder and the minimization of irreversible reactions can be attributed to the presence of more ordered carbon “shell” derived from pyrolyzed ACM [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0026" name="bbib0026" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0026"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">26</span></span></a><span><span><span>]. The <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/thermogravimetry" title="Learn more about thermogravimetry from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermogravimetry</a> (TGA) test also verified the orderliness of ACM (Fig. S4). Compared to CY, ACM has a higher </span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/thermal-decomposition" title="Learn more about thermal decomposition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">thermal decomposition</a><span><span> temperature at a mass loss of 4 %. This can be attributed to the more <a href="/topics/materials-science/amorphous-material" title="Learn more about amorphous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous</a> nature of CY, resulting in higher reaction activity under high-temperature conditions. Generally speaking, carbon with lower </span><a href="/topics/engineering/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a><span><span> and more defects are more prone to react at lower temperatures than those with higher <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/crystallinity" title="Learn more about crystallinity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">crystallinity</a><span>. And SAED results showed that the diffraction rings become increasingly sharp and clear from CY1200, CN1200 to CNA1200, indicating that <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/carbon-structure" title="Learn more about carbon structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon structure</a> has evolved from disordered to ordered. This result was consistent with </span></span><a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electron-microscope" title="Learn more about SEM from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SEM</a> and HRTEM. Through employed </span></span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/fast-fourier-transform" title="Learn more about Fast Fourier Transform from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Fast Fourier Transform</a><span> (FFT) characterization, it was observed that CNA1200 exhibited a greater interlayer spacing of 0.411 nm compared to CY1200 (0.367 nm) and CN1200 (0.385 nm). This is due to the fact that ACM has been treated with strong acids (sulfuric and nitric acids) and strong bases (sodium hydroxide), resulting in a higher N and S content. The presence of these heteroatoms facilitates the formation of C–N and C–S bonds with the carbon skeleton during pyrolytic coating with CN1200. Due to the destroyed conjugated π bonds and distorted 2D layers, thereby weakening the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/van-der-waals-force" title="Learn more about van der Waals forces from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">van der Waals forces</a><span> between the carbon layers, rendering it susceptible to <a href="/topics/materials-science/tensile-strain" title="Learn more about tensile strain from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">tensile strain</a> and expanding the interlayer spacing [</span></span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0027" name="bbib0027" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0027"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">27</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0018"><span><a href="/topics/engineering/ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a><span> and Raman tests were employed to investigate the crystallization characteristics of hard carbon. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-diffraction" title="Learn more about XRD from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XRD</a> test of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 revealed two prominent peaks around 24° (002 crystal planes) and 44° (101 crystal planes) (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>(a)). It represented the characteristic peak of typical <a href="/topics/engineering/amorphous-carbon" title="Learn more about amorphous carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">amorphous carbon</a> structure [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0028" name="bbib0028" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0028"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">28</span></span></a><span>]. In comparison to <a href="/topics/engineering/graphitic-carbon" title="Learn more about graphitic carbon from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitic carbon</a> material (2</span><em>θ</em><span> = 26.5°), the (002) diffraction peak of CNA1200 shifted to lower angles and demonstrated a larger interlayer spacing. For <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-anode" title="Learn more about carbon anode from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon anode</a> materials, the larger interlayer spacing can provide greater storage space and faster ion transport channels [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a>(b) displayed the results of Raman testing, revealing two distinct peaks at 1345 cm<sup>−1</sup> (D-band) and 1590 cm<sup>−1</sup> (G-band) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0030" name="bbib0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">30</span></span></a>]. The <em>I</em><sub>D</sub>/<em>I</em><sub>G</sub><span> of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 were 0.89, 1.03, and 0.95, suggesting that the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/graphitization-degree" title="Learn more about graphitization degree from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphitization degree</a> of coal-derived hard carbon decreases first and then increases. It also further confirms a tendency towards ordered carbon structure. The results of HRTEM, XRD, and Raman tests together demonstrated the validity of NaOH-controlled etching-thermal annealing and ACM coating in regulating the carbon structure.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0003"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr3.jpg" height="402" alt="Fig 3" aria-describedby="cap0003"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr3_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (516KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (516KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr3.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0003"><p id="spara003"><span class="label">Fig. 3</span>. (a) XRD and (b) Raman tests of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200; (c) XPS survey spectra and (d–f) the high-resolution O 1s spectra of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0019"><span>To investigate the interaction between NaOH and ACM with CY, <a href="/topics/materials-science/x-ray-photoelectron-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about XPS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">XPS</a> testing was performed on CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>(c)). Due to its low degree of <a href="/topics/engineering/coalification" title="Learn more about coalification from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">coalification</a><span>, CY1200 had an oxygen content of 14.5 %. After coating, the ACM will interact with CY and result in a loss of oxygen content to 11.1 %. However, due to the high oxygen content of ACM1200 (25.9 %), the change in oxygen content of CNA1200 was relatively small (Fig. S5(d–f)). These oxygen-containing functional groups endowed <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/polycyclic-aromatic-hydrocarbons" title="Learn more about polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons</a> with strong activity and can serve as reaction sites to induce uniform coating of ACM. As shown in </span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0003" name="bfig0003" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0003"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 3</span></span></a><span>(d–f), O 1s peak can be resolved into three components, corresponding to C=O (531 eV), C–OH and C–O–C (532 eV), -COOR (533 eV). Among them, the proportion of –COOR in CN1200 and CNA1200 had significantly increased. It can further participate in the <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> and chemical process of Na</span><sup>+</sup>, thus contributing to the sodium storage capacity in the slope region [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0031" name="bbib0031" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0031"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">31</span></span></a><span>]. The C 1s of CY1200 can be fitted as C–C (284.6 eV), C–OR (285.2 eV), C–OH (286.5 eV), and -COOR (288.7 eV). The C 1s of CN1200 and CNA1200 can be fitted to three peaks representing different chemical environments. These peaks were assigned to C–C (284.6 eV), C–OR (285.2 eV), and -COOR bonds (288.7 eV) (Fig. S5(a–c)). CNA1200 had the highest –COOR content of 14 % compared to CY1200 (2.68 %). The presence of –COOH functional groups not only enhanced the <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/wettability" title="Learn more about wettability from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">wettability</a><span><span> of the <a href="/topics/engineering/electrode-surface" title="Learn more about electrode surface from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode surface</a>, but also provided more active sites for </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion</a> storage (Fig. S6(a–c)). It provides a structural basis for achieving high specific capacity hard carbon anodes [</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0032" name="bbib0032" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">32</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0020">Besides ensuring appropriate interlayer spacing, pore structure also plays a crucial part in facilitating the diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup> [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0029" name="bbib0029" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0029"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">29</span></span></a>]. The pore structure of hard carbon was investigated by N<sub>2</sub> adsorption/desorption tests. CY1200 had a specific surface area (SSA) of 8 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. Due to the collapse of the pore structure after thermal annealing, CN1200 showed a decreased SSA of 2.49 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup>. In order to understand the abnormal decrease in SSA after NaOH controlled etching-thermal annealing process, the SSA of CY precursor annealed at lower temperature of 700 °C was examined, which showed a much higher value of 320.34 m<sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (Fig. S7(a–c)). It was presumed that the low SSA of CN1200 was due to the closure of open pores under high-temperature conditions and the N<sub>2</sub><span> adsorption/desorption test can only detect the presence of open pores. The existence of closed pores had a series of advantages, mainly including increased <a href="/topics/engineering/plateau-region" title="Learn more about plateau region from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">plateau region</a> capacity and thinner SEI. With ACM coating, the SSA of CNA1200 slightly increased to 10.75 m</span><sup>2</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(a)). In addition, CNA1200 and ACM1200 had similar N<sub>2</sub><span><span><span> adsorption/desorption curves and <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a> curves (Fig. S8(a, b)), which also indicated that the surface of CNA1200 was uniformly covered by ACM. All carbon materials exhibited a similar trend of wide pore size distribution, indicating the presence of </span><a href="/topics/engineering/micropore" title="Learn more about micropores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">micropores</a><span>, <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/mesopore" title="Learn more about mesopores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesopores</a>, and </span></span><a href="/topics/engineering/macropore" title="Learn more about macropores from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">macropores</a> (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a><span>(b)). The abundance of micropores in CN1200 and CNA1200 could potentially be attributed to the incomplete formation of closed pores, resulting in an <a href="/topics/engineering/average-pore-size" title="Learn more about average pore size from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">average pore size</a> ranging from 5 to 10 nm.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0004"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr4.jpg" height="416" alt="Fig 4" aria-describedby="cap0004"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr4_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (503KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (503KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr4.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0004"><p id="spara004"><span class="label">Fig. 4</span>. (a) N<sub>2</sub><span> adsorption/desorption isotherm, (b) <a href="/topics/materials-science/pore-size-distribution" title="Learn more about pore size distribution from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pore size distribution</a>, (c) SAXS diagram, and (d) comparison diagram of the fitting equation parameters and specific surface area parameters of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200.</span></p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0021"><span>To certify the presumption of closed pores creation and understand the total porosity of material, the carbon material was further investigated by <a href="/topics/food-science/small-angle-x-ray-scattering" title="Learn more about SAXS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAXS</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0033" name="bbib0033" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0033"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[33]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0034" name="bbib0034" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0034"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[34]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0035" name="bbib0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[35]</span></span></a><span>]. All <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/small-angle-x-ray-scattering" title="Learn more about SAXS from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SAXS</a> curves exhibited initial dip and sharp peaks in the range of 0.1–1 Å</span><sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(c)), indicating the existence of nanopores with random size and shape [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0036" name="bbib0036" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0036"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">36</span></span></a>]. CN1200 owned a more pronounced peak near 0.1 Å<sup>−1</sup><span>, indicating a larger radius of the closed <a href="/topics/materials-science/nanopore" title="Learn more about nanopore from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">nanopore</a>. Calculated by </span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#eqn0001" name="beqn0001" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="eqn0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Eq. (1)</span></span></a> (<em>A</em> value and <em>B</em> value are associated with the overall surface area of large pores and small pores, <em>Q</em> represents the scattering vector, and <em>D</em> denotes the constant background term. The diameter of the closed nanopore also can be calculated by <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-8-Frame" tabindex="0" is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></math></script></span>), the average value of closed pore size for CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 was 2.13, 2.51, and 2.71 nm, consistent with the SAXS results. Closed pores had important effect in facilitating ion transmission and storage in plateau areas.<span class="display"><span id="eqn0001" class="formula"><span class="label">(1)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-9-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo></mrow><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>A</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>Q</mi></mrow><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi></msup></mfrac><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>B</mi><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></mrow><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>4</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></mrow><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>a</mi><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></mrow><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msubsup><msup
