is="true" transform="translate(3080,445)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(9939,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(10940,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-44"></use></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi><mo is="true">(</mo><mi is="true">Q</mi><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">)</mo><mo is="true">=</mo></mrow><mfrac is="true"><mi is="true">A</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Q</mi></mrow><mi is="true">a</mi></msup></mfrac><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">B</mi><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow><mn is="true">4</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">(</mo><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">+</mo></mrow><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msubsup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Q</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mo is="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">D</mi></mrow></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-9"><math><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">I</mi><mo is="true">(</mo><mi is="true">Q</mi><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">)</mo><mo is="true">=</mo></mrow><mfrac is="true"><mi is="true">A</mi><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Q</mi></mrow><mi is="true">a</mi></msup></mfrac><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">B</mi><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow><mn is="true">4</mn></msubsup></mrow><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mrow is="true"><mo is="true">(</mo><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">+</mo></mrow><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">a</mi><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msubsup><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">Q</mi></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><mo is="true">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mfrac><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mi is="true">D</mi></mrow></math></script></span></span></span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0022">CN1200 presented the most significant difference between <em>A</em> value and <em>S</em><sub>BET</sub> among the three samples (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0004" name="bfig0004" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 4</span></span></a>(d)). The opposite trend of <em>S</em><sub>BET</sub> and <em>A</em><sub>SAXS</sub><span> values supported the hypothesis that more pores were produced after NaOH activation. Then majority of pores were restructured through thermal annealing to <a href="/topics/engineering/closed-form" title="Learn more about form closed from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">form closed</a> pores [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0037" name="bbib0037" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0037"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">37</span></span></a>]. Closed pore structures were crucial microstructure for sodium storage, which helped to achieve high plateau region capacity of hard carbon anode.</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0023">True density can also effectively characterize the closed pore structure. Throughout the entire testing process, helium gas (He) can enter almost all open pore structures. Therefore, the true density test can serve as a supplement to SAXS data. Using ideal graphite carbon material as reference value, its true density was 2.26 g cm<sup>-</sup><sup>3</sup>. With the progress of NaOH-controlled etching-thermal annealing, the true density decreased from 1.7169 (CY1200) to 1.564 g cm<sup>-</sup><sup>3</sup> (CN1200), indicating an increase in the number of closed pores. The results were consistent with SAXS tests. It demonstrated the successful preparation of closed pore structures.</div></section><section id="sec0010"><h3 id="cesectitle0014" class="u-h4 u-margin-m-top u-margin-xs-bottom">3.2. Characterization of electrochemical performance</h3><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0024"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(a–c) presents the results of galvanostatic charge–discharge curves to assess Na<sup>+</sup> storage capability. The curves displayed two sections: slope region (over 0.1 V) and plateau region (below 0.1 V). The slope and plateau region depend on the adsorption of Na<sup>+</sup> on functional groups and intercalation/de-intercalation in nanopores, respectively [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0038" name="bbib0038" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0038"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">38</span></span></a><span>]. Since the vast majority of carbon <a href="/topics/chemical-engineering/microcrystals" title="Learn more about microcrystals from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">microcrystals</a> existed in the form of graphite-like phases (it has smaller interlayer spacing), CY1200 demonstrated a capacity of 198.34 mAh g</span><sup>−1</sup> with Initial Coulombic Efficiency (ICE) = 43.54 % (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(a)). For CN1200, the NaOH-controlled etching-thermal annealing process produced more closed pore structures and expanded interlayer spacing, which can provide more Na<sup>+</sup>storage locations. Consequently, CN1200 had a higher Na storage capacity (279.35 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup>) compared with CY1200 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(b)). And the low-voltage plateau region exhibited a high capacity of 161.35 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, which accounts for the majority of the total capacity. It was notably higher than that noted for CY1200 (Fig. S9). After ACM coating, the surface disorder was further reduced, which can effectively limit the irreversible decomposition of electrolytes. Benefiting from this “core-shell” structure, CNA1200 owned Na storage capacity of 335.21 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> with ICE = 51.53 % (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(c)). CNA1200 demonstrated competitive reversible capacity compared with previously reported carbon materials [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0039" name="bbib0039" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0039"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[39]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0040" name="bbib0040" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0040"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[40]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0041" name="bbib0041" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0041"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[41]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0042" name="bbib0042" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0042"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[42]</span></span></a>]. To further improve the ICE of CNA1200, a pre-electrical treatment method was employed [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0043" name="bbib0043" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0043"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">43</span></span></a>]. This method had successfully increased the ICE from 51.53 % to 83.54 % (Fig. S10(a–c)). In addition, optimizing the electrolyte ratio, constructing more stable SEI membranes and pre-sodium strategies can also effectively improve ICE [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0044" name="bbib0044" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0044"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[44]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0045" name="bbib0045" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0045"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[45]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0046" name="bbib0046" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0046"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[46]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0047" name="bbib0047" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0047"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[47]</span></span></a>].</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0005"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr5.jpg" height="397" alt="Fig 5" aria-describedby="cap0005"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr5_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (540KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (540KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr5.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0005"><p id="spara005"><span class="label">Fig. 5</span>. (a–c) The charge-discharge curves of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 under the current density of 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup> for the first three cycles; (d) Rate performance of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 at different current densities; (e) Cycling performance of CNA1200 at 100 mA g<sup>−1</sup> current density; (f) The discharge specific capacity of CNA1200 and other hard carbon materials.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0025"><span>To further evaluate the reliability and performance stability of electrodes, rate performance and cycling <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/performance-test" title="Learn more about performance tests from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">performance tests</a> were conducted. When the current density increased from 20 to 500 mA g</span><sup>−1</sup>, the capacity of CN1200 showed a significant decay, dropping from 279.35 to 36.55 mAh g<sup>−1</sup><span>. This indicated that the defects in the <a href="/topics/engineering/layer-graphene" title="Learn more about graphene layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">graphene layer</a> were more conducive to the rapid diffusion of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> than closed pores under <a href="/topics/engineering/high-current-density" title="Learn more about high current density from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">high current density</a>, which was consistent with previous reports [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0048" name="bbib0048" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0048"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">48</span></span></a>]. Compared with CY1200 and CN1200, CNA1200 exhibited capacities of 335.21, 119.49 and 68.36 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 20, 200 and 500 mA g<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(d)). It indicated that ACM coating can significantly improve rate performance. This was mainly attributed to the effective reduction of disorder on the CN1200 surface by ACM, thereby maximizing the diffusion ability of Na<sup>+</sup>. The cycling stability of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 at a current density of 100 mA g<sup>−1</sup> is shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(e). CY1200 exhibited a low-capacity retention (75.3 %). After 200 cycles at 100 mA g<sup>−1</sup>, its capacity decreased from 168.7 to 127.1 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. The capacity retention of CN1200 (78.7 %) was slightly higher than that of CY1200. After 200 cycles at 100 mA g<sup>−1</sup>, the capacity decayed to 111.15 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>. In contrast, CNA1200 exhibited exceptional cycling performance, it maintained a reversible capacity of 173.44 mAh g<sup>−1</sup><span> when cycling 200 times. Moreover, it also showed remarkable capacity retention (91.8 %), which was significantly higher than CY1200 and CN1200. This corresponds to carbon microstructures with fewer defects and higher degree of order, which can reduce the rapid decay of capacity during long cycling processes. The improvement of rate and cycling performance indicated the effectiveness of <a href="/topics/engineering/surface-coating" title="Learn more about surface coating from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface coating</a> in improving kinetics.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0026">Indeed, CNA1200 exhibited outstanding sodium storage capacity and cycling stability, which can be profit from the following aspects: (1) Large interlayer spacing facilitated the intercalation/deintercalation of Na<sup>+</sup><span>; (2) Closed pores become the main active site in electrochemical sodium <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/storage-process" title="Learn more about storage process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">storage process</a><span>, which further improved the capacity in plateau region; (3) By forming a dense carbon layer, the interaction between the electrodes and electrolyte was significantly minimized. It helped reduce the possibility of side reactions, thereby improving the reversibility. And the presence of -COOH functional groups was beneficial for improving the storage and storage performance of slope areas. Benefiting from the <a href="/topics/engineering/synergistic-effect" title="Learn more about synergistic effect from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">synergistic effect</a> of these advantages, CNA1200 exhibited better sodium storage performance than previously reported carbon anodes (</span></span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0005" name="bfig0005" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 5</span></span></a>(f)) [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0018" name="bbib0018" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0018"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">18</span></span></a>,<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0049" name="bbib0049" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0049"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0050" name="bbib0050" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0050"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0051" name="bbib0051" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0051"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[51]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0052" name="bbib0052" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0052"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[52]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0053" name="bbib0053" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0053"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[53]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0054" name="bbib0054" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0054"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[54]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0055" name="bbib0055" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0055"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[55]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0056" name="bbib0056" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0056"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[56]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0057" name="bbib0057" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0057"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[57]</span></span></a>].</div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0027"><span>The EIS analysis was performed to explore the overall charge transfer characteristics of coal-based hard carbon (Fig. S11). And the corresponding equivalent circuit was also depicted. The semicircle and slope line in the <a href="/topics/engineering/nyquist-plot" title="Learn more about Nyquist plots from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">Nyquist plots</a><span> were related to the dynamic characteristics of <a href="/topics/engineering/charge-transfer-resistance" title="Learn more about charge transfer resistance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">charge transfer resistance</a> and Na</span></span><sup>+</sup><span> <a href="/topics/engineering/diffusion-kinetics" title="Learn more about diffusion kinetics from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion kinetics</a> [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0058" name="bbib0058" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0058"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[58]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0059" name="bbib0059" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0059"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[59]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0060" name="bbib0060" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0060"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[60]</span></span></a>]. CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 had charge transfer resistance of 500.3, 196, and 49.15 Ω, indicating the enhanced charge-transfer ability of CNA1200. This was attributed to the ACM coating, which effectively reduced the charge transfer resistance and enhanced the dynamic performance of CNA120. In addition, it's worth noting that CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 exhibited a pronounced steep slope in low-frequency area, which suggested the presence of rapid ion diffusion. Therefore, the surface coating can improve the chemical environment and fully stimulate the diffusion ability of Na<sup>+</sup><span>, thus improving the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/electrochemical-performance" title="Learn more about electrochemical performance from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical performance</a> in general.</span></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0028">In order to investigate the Na<sup>+</sup><span> storage behavior of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200, <a href="/topics/materials-science/cyclic-voltammetry" title="Learn more about CV from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">CV</a> tests were conducted. In the first cycle of all electrodes, two reduction peaks were observed at 0.5 and 0.01 V (</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>(a, d, g)). The reduction peak of 0.5 V disappeared during the second and third cycle, corresponding to the appearance of SEI. And the oxidation–reduction peak (0.01 V) corresponded to the intercalation and deintercalation process of Na<sup>+</sup>, indicating that the potential sodium storage mechanisms of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 depended on intercalation and deintercalation [<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0042" name="bbib0042" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0042"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">42</span></span></a>]. All of them exhibited highly overlapped CV curves, indicating that the coal-based carbon materials had good cycling stability. Compared with CY1200, CNA1200 had a stronger redox peak in CV curve, reflecting a more significant Na<sup>+</sup> intercalation/deintercalation process. To further investigate the Na storage mechanism of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200, CV tests were conducted at 0.2 to 1 mV s<sup>−1</sup>. In order to certify the quantitative contribution of capacitance and diffusion control, the CV curve was further calculated by the following formula:<span class="display"><span id="eqn0002" class="formula"><span class="label">(2)</span><span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-10-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><mtable displaystyle=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mtr is=&quot;true&quot;><mtd columnalign=&quot;right&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>i</mi><mspace width=&quot;0.33em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>(</mo><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;normal&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>V</mi></mrow><mo stretchy=&quot;true&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn></msub><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi><mspace width=&quot;0.33em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><mo linebreak=&quot;goodbreak&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo><mspace width=&quot;0.33em&quot; is=&quot;true&quot; /><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>k</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msub><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>v</mi></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>1</mn><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>/</mo><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="23.205ex" height="3.125ex" viewBox="0 -945.9 9991.1 1345.3" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.928ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true" transform="translate(167,0)"><g transform="translate(-16,0)"><g is="true" transform="translate(0,-97)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-69"></use></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(842,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-28"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(389,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-56"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1140,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-29"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2649,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-3D"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3705,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(4681,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(5718,0)"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2B"></use></g><g is="true"></g><g is="true" transform="translate(7049,0)"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6B"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(521,-150)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(8024,0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMATHI-76"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(485,412)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-31"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-2F"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(707,0)"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g></g></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mtable displaystyle="true" is="true"><mtr is="true"><mtd columnalign="right" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mspace width="0.33em" is="true"></mspace><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">V</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mspace width="0.33em" is="true"></mspace><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mspace width="0.33em" is="true"></mspace><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-10"><math><mtable displaystyle="true" is="true"><mtr is="true"><mtd columnalign="right" is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">i</mi><mspace width="0.33em" is="true"></mspace><mrow is="true"><mo stretchy="true" is="true">(</mo><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">V</mi></mrow><mo stretchy="true" is="true">)</mo></mrow><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">=</mo><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">1</mn></msub><mi is="true">v</mi><mspace width="0.33em" is="true"></mspace><mo linebreak="goodbreak" is="true">+</mo><mspace width="0.33em" is="true"></mspace><msub is="true"><mi is="true">k</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msub><msup is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi is="true">v</mi></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">1</mn><mo is="true">/</mo><mn is="true">2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></math></script></span></span></span>where <em>i</em> (V) is the current at a specific voltage, <em>ν</em> represents the scanning rate, and <em>k</em><sub>1</sub><em>ν</em> and <em>k</em><sub>2</sub><em>ν</em><sup>1/2</sup><span> refer to <a href="/topics/engineering/control-surfaces" title="Learn more about surface control from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">surface control</a> capacity and diffusion control capacity, respectively [</span><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bib0061" name="bbib0061" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bib0061"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">61</span></span></a>]. By calculation, it had been determined that the capacitance contribution of CY1200, CN1200, and CNA1200 was directly proportional to the scanning rate. This result suggested that the kinetics of Na<sup>+</sup> adsorption was faster than the kinetics of insertion. The capacitance for sodium storage in CNA1200 ranges from 50 % to 82 % at a scan rate of 0.2 to 1.0 mV s<sup>−1</sup> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 6</span></span></a>(h, i) and S12(i–l)). There was a similar trend in CY1200 and CN1200 (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0006" name="bfig0006" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 6</span></span></a>(b, c, e, f) and S12(a–h)). The enhanced capacitive storage of CNA1200 can accelerate the diffusion of Na<sup>+</sup> and prevent structural damage to the host material during high-rate charging and discharging, resulting in good rate performance.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0006"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr6.jpg" height="634" alt="Fig 6" aria-describedby="cap0006"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (709KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (709KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0006"><p id="spara006"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. (a, d, g) CV curves of CY1200, CN1200, CNA1200 at 0.1 mV s<sup>−1</sup>; (b, e, h) CV curve with calculated capacitive contribution of CY1200, CN1200, CNA1200 at 0.2 mV s<sup>−1</sup>; (c, f, i) Capacitive contributions of CY1200, CN1200 and CNA1200 at various scanning rates.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0029">To further investigate the sodium storage mechanism of CNA1200, the structure of carbon materials was tested at discharge to 0.2 and 0.001 V, charge to 0.2 and 2.5 V (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(a)). Firstly, the position of (002) peak in ex-situ XRD under different voltage conditions was compared (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(b)). As the discharge process progressed, the (002) peak shifted to the left, indicating the successful intercalation of Na<sup>+</sup> and resulting in an increased carbon interlayer spacing. During the subsequent charging process, the (002) peak returned to its original position. This indicates that CNA1200 exhibited an “intercalation-adsorption” mechanism. The carbon interlayer spacing at full discharge and full charge was determined through ex-situ TEM to be 0.4415 and 0.426 nm, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0007" name="bfig0007" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0007"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>(c–e)). Considering the comprehensive results of ex-situ XRD and TEM tests, it can be concluded that the sodium storage mode of CNA1200 primarily involves intercalation and adsorption.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0007"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr7.jpg" height="447" alt="Fig 7" aria-describedby="cap0007"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (836KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (836KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0007"><p id="spara007"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. (a) The first charge/discharge profiles and (b) ex-situ XRD tests of CNA1200 at original voltage, discharge to 0.2 V, discharge to 0.001 V, charge to 0.2 V and charge to 2.5 V. (c–e) The ex-situ TEM tests of CNA1200 at original voltage, discharge to 0.001 V and charge to 2.5 V.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="para0030">Considering the notable storage capacity, outstanding rate performance and cycling stability observed in coin cells, it was crucial to undertake further investigations into the electrochemical behavior of CNA1200 in full cells. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0008" name="bfig0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>(a) illustrates the assembly of full cell with an NVP cathode and CNA1200 anode. Through charge/discharge tests, it was found that the full cell had a voltage of 2.7–3.3 V, which was an important characteristic for achieving commercialization. The charge/discharge specific capacity at 0.1 C (1 C = 200 mA g<sup>−1</sup>) was 190.64/109.54 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> with ICE = 57.46 % (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0008" name="bfig0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>(b)). At 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2, and 5 C, the capacities can reach 109.58, 107.72, 105.42, 102.07, and 95.07 mAh g<sup>−1</sup>, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0008" name="bfig0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a>(c)). What's more, after cycled at 0.5 C for 200 times, NVP//CNA1200 maintained an impressive capacity retention of 94.64 % (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#fig0008" name="bfig0008" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="fig0008"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 8</span></span></a><span>(d)). It showed great potential for practical application and provided a new option for realizing low-cost and long-life <a href="/topics/engineering/sodium-ion-battery" title="Learn more about SIBs from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">SIBs</a>.</span></div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="fig0008"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr8.jpg" height="440" alt="Fig 8" aria-describedby="cap0008"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr8_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (513KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (513KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-gr8.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="cap0008"><p id="spara008"><span class="label">Fig. 8</span>. (a) The schematic image of the NVP//CNA1200 full cell; (b) The first three cycles of charge-discharge curves of NVP//LFC1200-LN at current density of 0.1 C in the voltage range of 1–4 V; (c) Rate performance of NVP//LFC1200-LN full cell at current densities from 0.1 to 5 C; (d) Cycling performance of the full cell at 0.5 C.</p></span></span></figure></div></section></section><section id="sec0011"><h2 id="cesectitle0015" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0031">In this work, a novel carbon skeleton (CNA1200) with a “core-shell” structure was prepared by NaOH-controlled etching-thermal annealing and surface coating, introducing closed pores and -COOH into coal-based hard carbon materials. The open pores produced by NaOH activation were partially closed under high-temperature conditions. It was confirmed by N<sub>2</sub><span> adsorption/desorption, SAXS, and true density test. These closed pores were the main active sites in the electrochemical sodium <a href="/topics/earth-and-planetary-sciences/storage-process" title="Learn more about storage process from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">storage process</a><span><span>, which can further improve the proportion of capacity in the plateau region. After ACM surface coating, a dense <a href="/topics/engineering/carbon-layer" title="Learn more about carbon layer from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon layer</a> was covered in CNA1200. It can reduce the electrode-electrolyte contact and enhance the </span><a href="/topics/engineering/electrical-conductivity" title="Learn more about electrical conductivity from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrical conductivity</a><span><span> of <a href="/topics/materials-science/carbon-particle" title="Learn more about carbon particles from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">carbon particles</a>; -COOH groups can provide additional active sites, which are beneficial for reversible sodium adsorption in slope regions. The synergistic effect between the construction of </span><a href="/topics/engineering/closed-pore-structure" title="Learn more about closed pore structure from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">closed pore structure</a> and -COOH endowed CNA1200 with excellent sodium storage performance. CNA1200 had the highest capacity of 335.21 mAh g</span></span></span><sup>−1</sup> at 20 mA g<sup>−1</sup> with ICE = 51.53 %. Moreover, it also demonstrated impressive capacity retention (91.8 %) even after undergoing 200 cycles. It implied that CNA1200 had excellent structural resistance and did not undergo structural collapse during long-term cycling. When evaluated in the full cell of NVP//CNA1200, it demonstrated a remarkable capacity of 109.54 mAh g<sup>−1</sup> at 0.1 C, while maintaining a voltage range of 2.7–3.3 V. This work not only designs a new practical coal-based hard carbon material, but also offers valuable insights for structural regulation of other hard carbon in the future.</div></section><section id="sec0011a"><h2 id="cesectitle0015a" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0031a"><strong>Haihua Wang:</strong> Conceptualization, Funding acquisition, Supervision, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Huizhu Niu:</strong> Data curation, Formal analysis, Methodology, Writing – original draft, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Kewei Shu:</strong> Funding acquisition, Supervision, Writing – review &amp; editing. <strong>Liyu Sun:</strong> Investigation, Methodology. <strong>Yu Wang:</strong> Data curation, Methodology. <strong>Yifan Du:</strong> Data curation. <strong>Yun Han:</strong> Data curation, Investigation. <strong>Cunguo Yang:</strong> Investigation. <strong>Yong-Mook Kang:</strong> Supervision, Writing – review &amp; editing.</div></section></div><section id="coi0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0016" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0033">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ack0001"><h2 id="cesectitle0017" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0034">The authors express sincere thanks to the <span id="gs0001">National Natural Science Foundation of China</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">21978164</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22078189</span></span></a> and <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0001"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">22105120</span></span></a>); the <span id="gs0002">Outstanding Youth Science Fund of Shaanxi Province</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0002"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2021JC-046</span></span></a>) and the <span id="gs0003">Special Support Program for high level talents of Shaanxi Province</span>; the <span id="gs0004">Innovation Support Program of Shaanxi Province</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0004"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2021JZY-001</span></span></a>); the <span id="gs0005">Key Research and Development Program of Shaanxi Province</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0005"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2020GY-243</span></span></a>); the <span id="gs0006">Special Research Fund of Education Department of Shaanxi</span> (No. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gs0006"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">20JK0535</span></span></a>); Supplementary materials</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="para0032a"><span class="display"><span class="e-component e-component-mmc1" id="ecom0001"><span class="article-attachment u-margin-xs-bottom"><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S100503022400570X-mmc1.docx" target="_blank" download="" title="Download Word document (14MB)"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" width="20" class="icon icon-text-document"><path d="M1 10v108h57.22L91 85.09V10H1m80 70.96L54.07 108H11V20h70v60.96zM43 100h10V80h20V70H43v30M25 32h42v10H25V32zm0 18h42v10H25V50z"></path></svg><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download Word document (14MB)</span></span></span></a></span></span></span></div></section></div></div><div class="related-content-links u-display-none-from-md"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-small" type="button"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Recommended articles</span></span></button></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="cebibl1"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="cebibsec1"><ol class="references" id="reference-links-cebibsec1"><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bbib0001" id="ref-id-bib0001" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a></span><span class="reference" id="sbref0001"><div class="contribution"><div class="authors u-font-sans">B. Feng, L. Xu, Z. Yu, G. Liu, Y. Liao, S. Chang, J. Hu</div></div><div class="host u-font-sans" id="ref-id-sbref0001">Electrochem. 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (15)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S1385894725035739"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Core-shell structured Bi@graphdiyne nanospheres enable high rate capacity and outstanding stability for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Chemical Engineering Journal</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0015">Bismuth is a promising anode material for sodium-ion batteries (SIBs) due to its ultrahigh theoretical volumetric capacity. However, its practical application is hindered by volume expansion during cycling, which leads to rapid capacity degradation. In this study, we reported an in-situ catalytic growth approach to synthesize Bi@GDY, a nanocomposite material comprising bismuth nanospheres encapsulated within a graphdiyne (GDY) core-shell structure. This unique architecture effectively mitigated volume expansion while enhancing the sodium storage performance, resulting in remarkable electrochemical properties, including high capacity, superior cycling stability, and reliable performance over a wide temperature range. The Bi@GDY anode demonstrated an outstanding capacity of 361.6&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> with a retention rate of 96.9&nbsp;% after 3000 cycles. In-situ and ex-situ characterizations revealed improved reaction kinetics and confirmed the characteristic alloying/dealloying mechanism. Furthermore, a Bi@GDY//NVP full cell delivered a high capacity of 183.2&nbsp;mAh g<sup>−1</sup> after 700 cycles with a retention rate of 86.9&nbsp;%, underscoring its potential for practical SIB applications. These findings position Bi@GDY as a highly promising anode material for next-generation SIBs.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S138589472410349X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">A simple and effective low-temperature pyrolysis control strategy to enhance the sodium storage performance of lignite-based carbon materials</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Chemical Engineering Journal</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0010">Coal is considered a promising carbon material precursor for sodium-ion batteries (SIB) anode due to its abundant reserves and low price. Nevertheless, the hard carbon prepared from coal generally exhibits poor sodium storage performance. Therefore, we propose a simple and effective strategy for controlling low-temperature pyrolysis to significantly improve the sodium storage performance of lignite-derived carbon anode material. By controlling the lignite pyrolysis stage at low temperatures, the ordering tendency of carbon material at high temperatures is reduced, leading to an increase in the content of pseudo-graphitic carbon with larger layer spacing. Simultaneously, the specific surface area of the resulting carbon is decreased and defects are effectively repaired. In comparison to the direct carbonization samples (DC-1400), which demonstrated a lower reversible capacity (269.4&nbsp;mAh/g) and ICE (82.9&nbsp;%), the low-temperature pyrolysis optimized sample (HM-420-6&nbsp;h) exhibited a higher reversible capacity (282.9&nbsp;mAh/g) and an excellent ICE (87.1&nbsp;%). When coupled with NaFe<sub>1/3</sub>Ni<sub>1/3</sub>Mn<sub>1/3</sub>O<sub>2</sub>, a full cell can achieve a high energy density of 216.1 Wh kg<sup>−1</sup>. The proposed strategy for controlling low-temperature pyrolysis offers a distinctive perspective on the mass preparation of high-performance SIB carbon anode materials.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24037952"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">The latest research progress on closed pore hard carbon for sodium-ion batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Storage</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0065">Hard carbons are promising anode materials for sodium-ion batteries due to their high specific capacity, strong conductivity, low cost, and environmentally friendly nature. The active sites responsible for Na<sup>+</sup> storage primarily include pores, interlayers and defects in hard carbon, among which closed pores play a crucial role in enhancing the capacity of hard carbon anode in the low voltage plateau region. This review introduced the structural feature and pores classification of hard carbon, as well as the influencing factors and Na<sup>+</sup> storage mechanism of closed pores. The latest strategies employed for constructing closed pores are also discussed. We hope that this review will provide valuable guidance for designing high-performance closed pore hard carbon anode.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/anie.202423864" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Reconfiguring Terminal Species of Bituminous Coal to Steer Hard Carbon toward High-Capacity and Fast Sodium Storage</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Angewandte Chemie - International Edition</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/adfm.202421790" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Simple Synthesis and Sodium Storage Analysis of Ultra-High Nitrogen-Doped Core-Shell Mesoporous Carbon Nanospheres</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2025, Advanced Functional Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.3390/nano14191604" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Sodium-Ion Battery at Low Temperature: Challenges and Strategies</span><svg 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Nanomaterials</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-secondary large-alternative button-alternative-icon-left" id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span     function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));

      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];

    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
      <span id="pendo-answer-rating"></span>

          PreviewHTML: { linebreaks: { automatic: true } },
          'HTML-CSS': { linebreaks: { automatic: true } },
          SVG: {
            scale: 90,
            linebreaks: { automatic: true }
          }
        });
      </script>
